articles.headline: U.N. Security Council Condemns Attacks on Health Workers in War Zones
articles.snippet: A new resolution raises an awkward question: Can the most powerful countries enforce the rules of war when they and their allies are accused of flouting them?
articles.abstract: A new resolution raises an awkward question: Can the most powerful countries enforce the rules of war when they and their allies are accused of flouting them?
articles.lead_paragraph: Warplanes level a hospital in the rebel-held half of Aleppo, Syria, killing one of the city’s last pediatricians. A Saudi-led military coalition bombs a hospital in Yemen. In Afghanistan, American aircraft pummel a hospital mistaken for a Taliban redoubt.

articles.headline: Populist Policies Let Brazil’s Tomorrow Slip Away
articles.snippet: The soaring hopes fed by a subsidized, state-directed, commodity-fueled economy have lately come crashing back to earth.
articles.abstract: The soaring hopes fed by a subsidized, state-directed, commodity-fueled economy have lately come crashing back to earth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not too long ago, Brazilians might have been counted as the most optimistic people in the world. From 2008 to 2013, as the United States and Europe grappled with the aftermath of a crisis wrought by blind trust in unfettered finance, Brazil’s income per person grew 12 percent after inflation. Wages soared. The poverty rate plummeted. Even income inequality narrowed.

articles.headline: China’s Steel Makers Undercut Rivals as Trade Debate Intensifies
articles.snippet: The steel industry is at the heart of discussions about the world economy that could become more complicated as global rule changes loom.
articles.abstract: The steel industry is at the heart of discussions about the world economy that could become more complicated as global rule changes loom.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARDIFF, Wales — With thunderous roars and flashes of blue light, an electric arc furnace at a steel mill in this industrial city melts 170 tons of scrap metal at a time, which is made into reinforcing bars for construction projects across Britain.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Deferred-Interest Promotions Are Back Under Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Nearly banned in 2009, such promotions are commonly offered on store-branded credit cards, and have been criticized as misleading and costly.
articles.abstract: Nearly banned in 2009, such promotions are commonly offered on store-branded credit cards, and have been criticized as misleading and costly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly seven years after a landmark overhaul of the credit card industry, regulators are renewing their scrutiny of a popular type of loan that can pack a big punch for consumers who don’t use it as intended.

articles.headline: ‘Flags of Our Fathers’ Author Now Doubts His Father Was in Iwo Jima Photo
articles.snippet: James Bradley says he believes his father, John Bradley, was involved in the first raising of the American flag, but not in the more famous second one.
articles.abstract: James Bradley says he believes his father, John Bradley, was involved in the first raising of the American flag, but not in the more famous second one.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It is an iconic photograph of American patriotism, depicting the heroism of service members raising the flag over Iwo Jima during World War II, which inspired the book and movie “Flags of Our Fathers.”

articles.headline: Google to Get Fiat Chrysler Minivans for Self-Driving Tests
articles.snippet: The partnership will equip 100 vehicles with technology to advance and expand Google’s development effort.
articles.abstract: The partnership will equip 100 vehicles with technology to advance and expand Google’s development effort.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The development of self-driving cars in recent years has been primarily a competition between technology companies and automakers working independently of each other.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Neal E. Boudette

articles.headline: Donald Trump All but Clinches G.O.P. Race With Indiana Win; Ted Cruz Quits
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump’s commanding victory over Senator Ted Cruz clears his path to reach the required number of delegates on the last day of primary voting on June 7.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump’s commanding victory over Senator Ted Cruz clears his path to reach the required number of delegates on the last day of primary voting on June 7.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump became the presumptive Republican presidential nominee on Tuesday with a landslide win in Indiana that drove his principal opponent, Senator Ted Cruz, from the race and cleared the way for the polarizing, populist outsider to take control of the party.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Patrick Healy

articles.headline: Takata Airbag Recall Is Said to Grow by 35 Million
articles.snippet: The move, which regulators may announce by Wednesday, would more than double the size of the largest safety recall in automotive history.
articles.abstract: The move, which regulators may announce by Wednesday, would more than double the size of the largest safety recall in automotive history.
articles.lead_paragraph: Regulators are expected to announce as early as Wednesday that at least 35 million additional airbags made by Takata will need to be fixed, according to a person briefed on the matter. This would more than double what is already the largest automotive recall in American history.

articles.headline: Ted Cruz Suspends His Campaign for President
articles.snippet: The senator’s run far exceeded many expectations, but he ultimately failed to persuade Republicans to rally behind him as an alternative to Donald J. Trump.
articles.abstract: The senator’s run far exceeded many expectations, but he ultimately failed to persuade Republicans to rally behind him as an alternative to Donald J. Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Less than a month ago, Senator Ted Cruz seemed to have done it.

articles.headline: With Donald Trump in Charge, Republicans Have a Day of Reckoning
articles.snippet: Some Republican operatives are so disgusted with their presumptive nominee that they have publicly declared their support for Mrs. Clinton.
articles.abstract: Some Republican operatives are so disgusted with their presumptive nominee that they have publicly declared their support for Mrs. Clinton.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republican elected officials, donors and strategists grappled uncomfortably on Wednesday with the inevitability of Donald J. Trump as their presidential nominee, an unexpectedly sudden denouement that left many in a state of political paralysis and others vowing to oppose the party’s new standard-bearer.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy, Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Moore’s Law Running Out of Room, Tech Looks for a Successor
articles.snippet: Unsure how long chip memory can reliably be doubled, an engineering group plans to create a new forecasting system for semiconductor innovation.
articles.abstract: Unsure how long chip memory can reliably be doubled, an engineering group plans to create a new forecasting system for semiconductor innovation.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For decades, the computer industry has been guided by a faith that engineers would always find a way to make the components on computer chips smaller, faster and cheaper.

articles.headline: Apple, Set to Move to Its Spaceship, Should Try More Moonshots
articles.snippet: To thrive in the next era of tech, one likely to be driven by data-rich online services, Apple needs to take a series of bigger, bolder risks.
articles.abstract: To thrive in the next era of tech, one likely to be driven by data-rich online services, Apple needs to take a series of bigger, bolder risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple is running out of parking spaces. If you drop by its Infinite Loop headquarters, you will find the place stretched beyond capacity. Even the valets, who double and triple-park the Teslas and Porsches that now flock to the world’s most valuable company, have given up finding free spots.
